div3.head: New Saddlery establishment.
div3.p:
--The undersigned have entered into a co-partnership under the style and firm of miles, Jennings & Co., for the purpose of conducting the Saddlery and Harness business in all its branches.
Each one of the firm being practically acquainted with the business, and giving our personal attention to all work entrusted to us, we earnestly solicit the patronage of all wanting articles in our line.
We have now in store a fine assortment of
Troopers' Saddles and Bridles.
Saddle Bags, &c.
To which we invite attention.
We will take orders for any articles to be made of leather, and pledge ourselves to give satisfaction both as to material and workmanship.

The undersigned wishes to inform his friends that he has not discontinued the Undertaking business, as some of his great friends has industriously circulated he had. I have on hand near two hundred Coffins, of all sizes from 22 inches to direct 4 inches, of all qualities, viz: Mahogany, Walnut, Rosewood Color, Poplar.
Pine, &c.

Also, two Hearses, Hacks, Buggies, and everything in the Undertaking line, equal, if not superior to any in the city or State; at all hours, day or night, at 20 or 30 per cent. less than can be bought in the city — for cash.
div3.closer:
J. W. Satter White,
Corner Franklin and 18th sts. au 1--2w*

div3.head: Southern Steam privateer Company.
div3.p: --Persons desirous of promoting this branch of our National defence against our enemy can yet find a few shares of the stock to subscribe for, at their office, No. 13 Pearl street, first floor, where all information can be had. Shares $100 each, in an A No. 1 Ship.
Blackberry Brandy something very nice, made by one who understands the art, for sale by R. W. Powers, Druggist.

div3.head: Lost.
div3.p:

A suitable reward will be paid to the finder, if delivered to me at Cox's Shed, Dock street, or left at this office.

The above reward will be paid for the recovery of the Trunk with its contents uninjured.

closer.signed: Gen'l. Sup't. Va. C. R. R.

div3.p:
Came to my house, on Broad st., opposite the old Fair Grounds, on the 4th inst., a Black Cow, with a white bag, and the end of her tail white; long horns, and one teat smaller then the rest.
The owner will come forward, prove property, pay expenses, and take her away.

div3.head: Lost.
div3.p:
--On Thursday, 13th of June, an order on T. H. Wynne, for the sum of $125, receipted on the back for $100, for work done Luke McKenny by Wm. J. McCloy. I forewarn all persons from trading for the same, as payment has been stopped.
I will give a liberal reward for the same if left at the Stone-yard corner of 8th and Arch streets, near the Petersburg Depot, with Mr. Jas. McCaulny.

div3.head: Salt Sulphur Springs.--
div3.p: The report in circulation that the Salt Sulphur Springs, Monroe county, Va., are not open for visitors, is unfounded. I have made ample arrangements for the accommodation of all persons who desire a secure and healthy place of summer resort.

div3.head:
Hot Springs,
Bath county, Va.
nature's remedy for Chronic Diseases.
div3.p:
The Hotel at this place is now open for the reception of visitors.
As a remedy in Chronic cases of Gout, Neuralgia, Rheumatism, Diseases of the Liver, Spinal Irritation, Paralysis, &c., the Thermal Waters here are excelled by nothing ever known to the human race.
Their alternative and curative powers are unsurpassed by those of any other Mineral Water on the face of the globe.
An abundant supply of Ice on hand.

Board $12 per week.
Children under 12 years of age, and colored servants, half price.
Hot Baths, each 50; pleasure do. 25

N. B.--As there is now only a tri-weekly line from Staunton to this place, passengers desiring to come directly here should leave Richmond or any point on the Central Railroad, on Tuesday, Thursday or Saturday.

div3.head: To the public.
div3.p:
--I understand a report is in circulation that "the Montgomery White Sulphur Springs" are used and occupied as a barracks for soldiers.
The report is absolutely false.
The establishment has been opened for the reception of visitors since 20th of May, and has now about 250 guests.
The proprietor is prepared to accommodate, in the most comfortable manner, one thousand persons, and to furnish them with every delicacy the country affords.
Visitors can have hourly communication with every portion of the South by means of the Telegraph.
The Springs are within a mile of the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad, and connected by a railroad belonging to the company.
They are in a region remote from the theatre of war — in no danger of invasion from any quarter — in the midst of a brave, loyal and faithful population, which have contributed men and money to the cause of the South with a liberality and patriotism unsurpassed.
Lewis F. J. Amiss, Proprietor.
Memphis Appeal and Charleston (S. C.) Mercury will publish ten times each, and forward bill to Springs for payment.

div3.head:
White Sulphur Springs,
Greenbrier county, Va.
div3.p: Reduction of charges.
Owing to the embarrassed state of the country, the White Sulphur Springs Company has determined upon the following charges:
$2.50 Per Day.
14.00 Per Week.
50.00 Per Month.

White Servants two-thirds price.
Children under 10 and over 2 years, and colored Servants, half price.
An abundant supply of Ice has been secured.

div3.head:
Bath Alum Springs,
Virginia,
div3.p: 10 miles from Millboro' Depot, Virginia Central Railroad.
to Families and individuals who wish A quiet and Pleasant Summer retreat.--The place will be well kept, and with special reference to the comfort of families.
Board--$10 per week for two weeks, and for all time over two weeks, $1 per day. Children and servants half price.
An abundance of Ice on hand.

div3.head: Ranaway
div3.p:
--From the subscriber, on Monday, the 5th inst., a Negro Woman, named Betty.
Said woman is about 5 feet 3 inches high, dark complected, with a lighter shade on both cheeks.
I believe she is now somewhere in the town of Sidney, as she was last heard of in the neighborhood of Mr. Pace's. A reward of five Dollars will be paid for her delivery to me, or if placed in any jail, so that I can get her again.
div3.closer:
Joseph Davis,
214 Broad street. au 8--ts

div3.head: $100 reward.
div3.p:
--For the delivery to me of my Carriage Driver, Beverly. He is twenty-seven years old; color, black; six feet high; face covered with short beard, and moustache; large eye-brown and curling eye-lashes.
He probably travels in a dark grey mixed summer coat, or blue cloth with brass buttons, and carpet-bag.
He says he has read Shakespeare, and may travel with a forged pass, and shave off his beard when he reads this.
He has relatives at Dr. R. H. Stewart's, in King George, and at Mrs. Dr. Frank Taliaferro's, in Orange, with whom he has been recently corresponding by letter.
His object being evidently to escape, he is doubtless lurking about the shore of the Potomac, or making his way Northward, and may be about our encampments.
The above reward will be paid if caught over fifty miles from Fredericksburg; otherwise, $50

div3.head: Runaway Negro.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the service of the Virginia & Tennessee Railroad Company, in June last, a slave named Abraham.
He is about 25 years of age, 6 feet high, and of a dark brown color, usually wears a handkerchief on his head, and has a scar on his forehead or face.

Abraham belongs to Capt. John Buford, of Bedford county, and it is supposed that he is now about Richmond, or at one of the volunteer encampments.
A liberal reward will be paid for him.
div3.closer:
E. H. Gill,
Gen'l Sup't. Va. & Tenn. Railroad.
Lynchburg, July 16, 1861. jy 16--lm

div3.head:
Richmond & Danville Railroad,
Superintendent's office,
div3.p: for the South and Southwest.
Richmond and Danville Railroad.
On and after Monday, Aug. 12, the Passenger Trains will run as follows:

Mail Train leaves Richmond Daily, (Sundays included) at 7.20 A. M.; but on Sunday the Train goes to Burkeville only, connecting there with the trains on the South-Side Railroad for the South and Southwest.
Mail Train leaves Danville Daily, (except Sundays,) at 5.57 A. M., and reaches Richmond at 1.45 P. M.
On Sundays there will be a Mail Train from Burkeville to Richmond, leaving Burkeville on the arrival of the Train from the South and Southwest at 10.45 A. M., and reaching Richmond at 1.45 P. M.
Trains from Richmond connect at Burkeville with the Trains on the South-Side Railroad for Lynchburg and the South and Southwest daily.
The Train from Danville connects at Burkeville with South-Side Railroad Trains for Petersburg and Norfolk.
Through Tickets can be procured and baggage will be checked through to the following points:

div3.head:
Daily line
on James River.
div3.p: --to Forts Powhatan and Jamestown, Grove and Stone House Wharfs.--The Steamer Curtis Peck, Capt. J. H. Freeman, will leave the wharf at Rocketts regularly, every morning, (except Sundays,) at 5 o'clock, for the above places, and return same day, about 9½ o'clock P. M., touching at all of the regular landings, going and returning.
Passage to Grove or Stone Wharf, $3--Meals extra, 50 cents each.
The Curtis Peck will connect with a line of Coaches, running to Yorktown, at the Grove Wharf, and through tickets, to Yorktown and return, will be given on the boat for $5 meals extra, 50 cents each.

Freight Trains — Change of hours.--Leave Richmond daily (except Sundays) at 5 A. M.; West Point daily (except Sundays) at 12:15 P. M.
Freight received at Richmond daily (except Sundays) until 5 P. M.

div4.p: You will cause instructions to be issued to the proper officers of your Road, to permit no one to pass over the same out of the city who shall be without a permit from the Governor, or some one authorized by him to give passports.
Officers producing their commissions from the Government of the Confederate States, or other States of the Confederacy, or their orders, will be permitted to pass without other authority.
div4.closer:

T. H. Wynne,

div3.head: Notice to Travellers.
div3.p:
--Passengers leaving Richmond or Petersburg in the afternoon, will not make A Continuous Connection South of Wilmington.
In consequence of the present temporary arrangement of schedule from Richmond South, by this train, passengers will lay over in Wilmington from 7 A. M., until 7 P. M.
By leaving Richmond or Petersburg in the morning, there will be a continuous connection all the way through.

Notice to the public, New and important Arrangement, 1861.
The Adams Express Company respectfully announce to the public that they have arranged to run their Express Twice Daily from New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore to Richmond, thereby affording unusual facilities for obtaining their freight and packages in the shorten possible time.

Expresses leave New York at 1, 5 and 6 o'clock P. M. Expresses leave Philadelphia at 6 A. M., and 11 P. M. Expresses leave Baltimore at 4.35 A. M. and 4.20 P. M., arriving in Richmond at 1.30 A. M. and 1 P. M.
Expresses leave Richmond for New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore, and all points North and West, at 6.30 A. M. and 6.00 P. M.
Freight and packages should in all cases be at our office one hour before the departure of the Trains.
Expresses for the South leave Richmond Twice Daily, at 4.30 A. M., 2.45 P. M.

The Adams Express Company feel that they can guarantee to the public civility, attention and satisfaction in all their intercourse with their officers in Richmond, and nothing will be left undone on their part to meet the wants of their customers.

Freight and packages arriving by the Express from the North at 3 o'clock P. M., will be delivered immediately, thereby giving to our customers an advance of twelve hours over our arrangements heretofore.

steamer Expresses, to and from New York, Semi-Weekly.
Freights delivered immediately upon the arrival of the ship.
heavy and Light freights, packages, money, Bonds, Legal Documents, &c., forwarded with safety and dispatch to all parts of the United States, Canada, and Europe.
Notes, Drafts and Bills, with or without Goods, collected at all accessible points; throughout the United States, and prompt returns guaranteed.
Slaves forwarded by each of our Expresses, in charge of careful and reliable Messengers.
Tobacco and other samples carried at low rates.
All freights promptly called for and delivered without extra charge.
For further information, please call at our office, 222 Main street.

div3.head: Travelers to the North.
div3.p: --1861. Northern Central Railway.--Trains leave Calvert Station, Baltimore, daily, (except Sunday,) at 8.30 A. M., and at 5.30 P. M., for Niagara Falls, (fare only ten dollars,) Buffalo, Owego, Oswego, Toronto, Hamilton, all parts of Western New York and Canada, for Detroit, Chicago, Cincinnati, St. Louis, and all parts of the West, Northwest and Southwest.
Travelers can go to Detroit, Chicago, Milwaukie, &c., via Niagara Falls, at the same cost as by any other route.

A new route to New York is now open by this Road, via Harrisburg and Jersey City, with only one change of cars.
Fare, $5. Take the 5.30 A. M., train and go through by daylight, over first-class Roads and through a beautiful country.
Try it.
Buy tickets only to Baltimore.

div3.head: Artificial Teeth.
div3.p:
--the Cheoplastic and Vulcanite Process.--G. W. Jones, Dentist, having the right for the above mode of making Teeth, and being satisfied of its absolute superiority over all other methods, can with confidence commend it to those desiring full or partial sets of teeth, and especially such as may be dissatisfied with those they are now using.--The perfect adaptation of the plate to the mouth, and the section thereby secured, enables him to insert one or more teeth without clamps. This method having been adopted by those standing highest in the profession, North and South, testimonials will be given and specimens exhibited to those wishing to see them.
Sets of Teeth, on gold or any other plate, will, of course, be made for those preferring them.
Filling, Cleansing, Extracting, and all other operations gently and thoroughly performed.
Teeth extracted by Electricity, without pains.
Office on Main street, opposite Corinthian Hall.
